asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food if he will be seeking an extension of the Euro loan scheme for farmers which was introduced in September 1986 and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food if he has satisfied himself that the present system of allocation of milk distribution is not being abused; if he will make a statement regarding the suggestion that the additional increments to milk quotas are being purchased; and if his attention has been drawn to any such abuses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that the milk quota system is being operated in accordance with the Community regulations. Under these regulations the sale and leasing of quotas can take place only if the lands to which the quotas are attached are also sold and leased. No cases involving sales or leases of quota without the land attached have been brought to my Department's notice. Officials of my Department monitor quota transfers and if they become aware of irregular transactions the penalties provided for in the national regulations will be applied to the parties concerned and the full super-levy charged on all milk deliveries from the lands in question.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Working Party on Agriculture.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food given the national importance to the economy of agriculture and the general agreement between the majority of the members of all parties on the need for better management of the public finances, his views on whether the working party on agriculture should include members from all the interested political parties; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food if he has satisfied himself with the progress to date of his working party on agriculture in the context of the Government's forthcoming programme for economic recovery; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food the steps, if any, he intends to take to reduce the seasonal imbalance between winter and summer milk production; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: The seasonal nature of our milk production pattern derives from the fact that the dairy industry is grass-based. This in turn results in the concentration of milk production during the grass growing season and a reduction in the seasonal imbalance depends primarily on the economics of producing milk outside that season. Such a reduction can be achieved by the further development of products capable of providing returns to producers sufficient to cover the extra costs involved in winter milk production. The main focus of Government policy on the milk sector is designed to encourage the production of products of this type.

asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food the reason his Department have refused repeated requests from the Joint Sheep Dipping Committee of Counties Cork, Kerry, Waterford and South Tipperary to introduce a second compulsory dipping each year for a trial period of three years and thereby eliminate sheep scab disease; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: The dipping of sheep for the purpose of controlling and ultimately eradicating sheep scab is a statutory obligation on farmers under the Sheep Dipping Order, 1965. The order originally required dipping to be carried out twice each year — in summer and autumn — but was amended in 1977 to provide for one dipping only, to be carried out in the period 15 September to 31 January. The change was made on the recommendation of a special deapartmental veterinary committee which studied sheep scab and determined that the mite which causes scab does not generally become active until late autumn or winter. Experience elsewhere has shown that the only effective way to control the disease is by proper dipping at that time of year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Clare Bovine TB Incidence.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Food if the incidence of tuberculosis in cattle has been increasing in County Clare; if he will designate north-west Clare as a special area for particular attention by his departmental veterinary surgeons; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy) Michael O'Kennedy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. O'Kennedy)
Speaker.P: The bovine tuberculosis situation in County Clare has shown a marked improvement in recent years. The number of herds restricted due to TB has fallen from a peak of 605 in November 1985 to 438 in November 1986 and to 266 at present. This improvement should be maintained during the course of the present round.

High levels of bovine TB have been present traditionally in north-west Clare notably in the Burren, though improved results have been achieved there also in recent years. My Department will be devoting particular attention to this area during the present round with a view to bringing about a further reduction in disease levels over the coming months.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - VAT Due by Hotel Industry.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance arising out of his reply to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 26 and 29 of May 28, 1987, the reason records are not available on an annual basis, indicating the amount of VAT due by the hotel industry, when non-revenue sources can provide statistical information indicating the approximate amounts due each year; the source or sources from which the Comptroller and Auditor General can report the amount due at the end of each year and include such information in his annual report; if he intends providing the information requested to members of the Dáil and the taxpayers of this country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Revenue Commissioners that, since many traders engage in a number of different business activities, the commissioners are therefore not in a position to identify VAT liability for specific trading activities from VAT returns. Accordingly, use is made of statistics from other sources e.g. consumer expenditure data, where available, in order to furnish estimates of VAT payable by a particular trade sector, such as the hotel industry.

The statistics of VAT due which are included in the annual reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General are of a global nature and are furnished from Revenue records. These records are compiled from traders' returns and from estimates of tax raised by the Revenue. They are not compiled on a sectoral basis.
I am informed by the commissioners that the improvement of statistical information within the resources available is kept under continuing review.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance his views that the tax on hydrocarbon oils levied on the ESB, at twice the rate levied on other companies, is unfair and an additional tax on electricity consumers which raises the cost of electricity; if the Government intend to reduce the tax to the same level as charged to private industry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. O'Malley Mr. P. O'Malley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the plans, if any, he has to reduce the £16 per tonne hydrocarbon tax on fuel oil used by the ESB in order to reduce the cost of electricity to consumers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 84 and 85 together.

I assume the Deputies are referring to the rate of excise duty on residual fuel oil used by the ESB which is 7p per gallon and the rate of excise duty on the same oil used by industry which is 3½p per gallon.

On 1 December, 1981 the rate of excise duty on residual fuel oil used by industry was reduced. This reduction was intended to be of direct benefit to manufacturing industry and accordingly it was not extended to cover the residual fuel oil used by the ESB.

In the present very difficult budgetary situation any reduction in this tax would have to be compensated for elsewhere. It is not a question, therefore, of whether this amount of tax should be raised but one of where it should be sought and the Government consider that the present mixture of taxes, including the excise duty on residual fuel oil used by the ESB, is necessary in present circumstances. It is not proposed at present, therefore, to reduce the rate of excise duty on residual fuel oil used by the ESB.

MainHeading.P: It is relevant in this context to point out that consumers of electricity benefit from the fact that electricity is not subject to VAT. This is in contrast with the situation of other fuel users since all other fuels are subject to VAT.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Derrynane, Kerry, Burial Ground.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if the Office of Public Works will allow Kerry County Council to extend the burial ground at Derrynane, Caherdaniel, County Kerry; if discussions are taking place between officials of the Office of Public Works and Kerry County Council regarding same; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacSharry) Ray MacSharry
Speaker.P: At the request of Kerry County Council the Commissioners of Public Works agreed to lease an area of ground to the council for the extension of the burial ground at Abbey Island in Derrynane Historic Park in the Caherdaniel area. The offer was subject, inter alia, to an archaeological investigation of the site to ensure that there were no archaeological remains in that area. A preliminary excavation carried out in 1985 found that there were archaeological remains there and established that portion of the site should be preserved. A further excavation would be required before a decision could be made as to whether grave spaces could be made available in another part of the site. Kerry County Council have indicated that they have no funds for further excavation.

A meeting recently took place between an official of Kerry County Council and an official of the Office of Public Works and a possible alternative site for the extension of the burial ground was identified. I understand that Kerry County Council are considering the suitability of this alternative location.

Speaker.P: The Department's office in Maynooth is run by a branch manager who provides office accommodation and staffing under contract.

In recognition of the difficulties at the office in Maynooth, revised signing arrangements which provide for the signing and payment of individuals over an extended four-day period were introduced last year and this alleviated the pressure to some degree. The branch manager also endeavoured to improve the situation by purchasing a dwelling house which he intended to convert into an employment office but was refused permission to do so by the planning authority. This decision was upheld on appeal by An Bord Pleanála.
It is accepted that the existing premises are not entirely satisfactory and the question of acquiring alternative suitable accommodation is being pursued by the branch manager.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy the total cumulative balance of payments effects of the Kinsale Gas field to-date; the estimated total balance of payments effects to the economy in today's prices for the life of the field; the cumulative payments from Bord Gáis Éireann to the Exchequer to-date; the anticipated dividends expected to be paid for each of the next three years; if these payments have been reduced, or are expected to be reduced because of assistance by Bord Gáis Éireann to Dublin Gas; and if so, by how much.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke) Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: The balance of payments effect of the gas from the Kinsale Gas field to date is about £1,300 million. It is difficult to estimate the balance of payments effect to the entire field but given that about 60 per cent remains to be consumed a rough indication of the total balance of payments effect might be £3,000 million.
To the end of 1986 BGE had paid £245 million to the Exchequer. It is not anticipated that any dividend payments to the Exchequer will be made by BGE over the next few years.

These nil payments are due to a combination of low oil prices and hence lower profit margins for BGE and the need to support the development of gas distribution in Dublin and other centres along with further already planned capital expenditure on gas infrastructure. Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke) Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: The total amount of royalties paid to-date by Marathon in respect of the Kinsale Head gas field is £25,633,717. For 1987, the estimated royalty payment is £2,600,000.

It is not possible to project accurately the level of royalty payments over the next ten years as these payments are related to the annual contract quantities agreed between Marathon and BGE and are also related to variation in the price of the gas which is determined by an oil price related formula. Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy the reason Bord Gáis Éireann is spending £20 million on compression facilities to maintain the flow of gas; if the production of gas is the responsibility of Marathon or Bord Gáis Éireann if major capital works are being undertaken by Bord Gáis Éireann to upgrade the Dublin-Cork pipeline; and if these could not have been anticipated prior to its construction and if he will make a statement in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke) Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: While the production of gas offshore is the responsibility of Marathon, the further transmission of gas within Ireland is the responsibility of Bord Gáis Éireann. The decision to build the Cork-Dublin 18” pipeline was contingent on a compressor station being constructed at a later date. The diameter of the pipeline was decided after an economic evaluation of the size and timing of compression facilities, and the decision taken then was the most economical one. A total expenditure of IR£18.4 million was approved and it is expected that this figure will not be exceeded. No capital works are being undertaken by Bord Gáis Éireann to upgrade the Cork to Dublin pipeline.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Energy the size and expected lifetime of the Kinsale Head gas reservoir; the Government's policy, if any, on the rate of depletion of the reserves and on the best possible usage, from the national and economic and social standpoint, of these reserves in the future; his views on whether the best possible usage of the resource has been obtained, and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke) Minister for Energy (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: Total gas reserves are estimated at 1.353 trillion cubic feet. Based on current gas offtakes and estimated reserves, gas could continue to be extracted from the Kinsale Head field until the end of the century at least. Annual offtakes from the field are subject to the provisions of the contract between Marathon and BGE. Under a decision of the Supreme Court of July 1986, Marathon are not obliged to deliver more than 60 billion cubic feet per annum from the Kinsale Head field.
I am satisfied that every effort has and will continue to be made to obtain the best possible return for the economy from the available reserves.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Kerry Harbour Designation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Marine the reason he revoked a decision of the previous Minister for Fisheries regarding mariculture at Smerwick harbour, Ballydavid, County Kerry; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that such a decision, if made, could cause loss of life; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.P: A new system of licensing of fish farming projects in the sea was provided for in section 54 of the Fisheries Act, 1980, which section was brought into effect in August 1983. The new system normally requires the holding of a public inquiry to determine whether the Minister will make a designation order for a particular area designating it as one in which it shall be lawful to engage in aquaculture in suitable blocs subject to licence.

Notice of intention to designate Smerwick harbour was published on 18 July 1986 and a public inquiry was held on 16 September 1986. The matter of designation has since been under consideration and my predecessor indicated in February 1987 that as far as he was concerned he would not proceed with the designation of Smerwick harbour. He also arranged for officials of my Department to carry out a detailed evaluation and report on the various representations and objections made prior to, during, and after the hearing of the public inquiry, regarding the designation proposal. This report has recently been completed and submitted to me. I am currently reviewing the matter and will make a decision in the near future. The Deputy can rest assured that safety at sea is a major factor when designation of an area is being considered and it will be taken fully into account in my deliberations.

Section 8 of the Building Societies (Amendment) Act, 1986 does not require representation from mortgage holders but, in my opinion, consumer interests should be adequately represented on the council when they are established.

asked the Minister for Labour in view of the careers information services being scrapped for post primary schools the alternative measures, if any, he has to provide a vital careers service to schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: Because of serious shortage of staff within the Department to deal with demand for places on various temporary employment schemes, in particular the social employment scheme, the staffing of all sections of the Department of Labour, including that dealing with careers information, is being reviewed at present. Demands on the careers information service decreases from the time intermediate, group and leaving certificate examinations begin until second-level schools open again after the summer holidays.

In these circumstances, it has been decided to assign staff from the careers information service on a temporary basis to the other sections. A final decision has not been taken about the future of the careers information service. Such a decision will be taken in the context of the integrated service for school leavers to be provided by An Foras Áiseanna Saothair.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Noonan, Limerick West) Michael J. (Limerick West) Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick West): Details of the 1987 estimate and the 1986 out-turn in respect of expenditure by my Department on telecommunications and postal services are as follows—

MainHeading.P: Expenditure on these services is monitored on an on-going basis and is kept at the lowest level possible consistent with requirements.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the building project at St. John's national school, Sligo; and when sanction will be given for work to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The authorities of St. John's national school, Sligo, have prepared tender documentation for a proposed extension to their school comprising a general purposes area and certain ancillary accommodation, and now seek authorisation to proceed to invite tenders. Because, however, of the prior claims of a large number of national school building projects involving the provision of urgently needed classroom accommodation, which are also seeking authorisation to invite tenders, and because of the difficult financial position generally, I am not in a position at this time to authorise the invitation of tenders for the project at St. John's national school. The Primary Buildings Branch of my Department will be keeping the position under review and will be in touch with the school authorities as soon as it may be possible to authorise further progress with their project.

asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the provision of a new building for Ballymote national school, County Sligo; the definite decisions which have been taken; the plans, if any, which have been completed or started for the building; when it is expected that work might commence; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Arising from the agreement reached between the school authorities and my Department on the amalgamation of the convent girls' and the boys' national schools at Ballymote, County Sligo, my Department have asked their professional officers to undertake a feasibility study in relation to the extension of the convent national school so as to provide the required accommodation of eight classrooms, a general purposes area and the usual ancillary accommodation. My Department will communicate the outcome of this study to the school authorities. At this early stage of architectural planning, I am not in a position to say when the actual work of building may commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Community and Literacy Education Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the amount provided in the 1987 Estimates of Vocational Educational Committees for adult education, showing separately the amount for pay and non-pay the amount provided in 1986; and the amount provided in the Estimates from the former Government in January 1987.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The amount of money allocated to the VEC's in respect of the Community and Literacy Education Scheme for 1987 is £400,000 compared to £350,000 in 1986. The corresponding provision included in the Estimates for the Public Service 1987, published by the previous Government, was £500,000.

In relation to the question of funding for the other types of adult education courses which, in the main are expected to be self-financing, I refer the Deputy to my reply to a similar question, No. 642, from her on this subject on 28 April 1987.

MainHeading.P: The Estimates for the Public Service 1987 as published by the previous Government provided for an overall allocation in subhead A2 of the Post-Primary Vote for annual grants to Vocational Education Committees. In determining this allocation, a specific amount was not designated for Adult Education, apart from the Community and Literacy Education Scheme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Swords Vocational School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether her Department have indicated to the County Dublin Vocational Education Committee that they will not sanction the purchase of a site for the construction of a new school at Swords, County Dublin; if her Department have indicated to that Vocational Education Committee that they should evict the community council from the former school premises at North Street, so as to use it for school purposes; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department are proceeding on the basis of incorporating the old vocational school building in Swords into an expanded school complex located on adjoining lands. It is estimated that, by proceeding in this way, there will be a saving of at least £1/4 million relative to the cost of building an entire new school on another site. The purchase of lands by the VEC, other than the lands adjoining the old vocational school, does not now arise and will not be sanctioned by my Department.

MainHeading.P: My Department have indicated to the VEC that they should make whatever arrangements are necessary so that the two rooms and associated facilities in the permanent building at the old vocational school, which are at present occupied by the community council, are available from next September for school purposes. Because of the anticipated extra numbers next September, there is no alternative to this course of action. There is no further room on the existing site for an additional two prefabricated classrooms and, even if the situation were otherwise, it would not be reasonable to accommodate students in yet more prefabricated classrooms whilst community groups occupied some of the permanent accommodation which was originally provided for the students' needs. It would not be acceptable, in the short term, to incur expenditure on more temporary classrooms than necessary or, in the longer term, to build new permanent accommodation duplicating the school accommodation occupied by the community council.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether she will arrange payment of the balance of £5,000 grant due to the trustees of the Clonakilty community hall, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The sum in question, £5,245, represents an unpaid balance of grants amounting to £186,000 allocated to Clonakilty community hall association in respect of the construction of a community recreational centre. The sum is being retained, in accordance with the normal practice in relation to such grants, pending production by the association of certain documentation requested by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Science Subjects in Post-Primary Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the new Minister of State for Science and Technology has been asked to undertake any consideration of the acknowledged need to have a greater emphasis on science and technology in post-primary schools; if so, the terms of reference which have been given to him; if not, if she will ask him to carry out a detailed survey of the teaching of scientific and technological subjects in post-primary schools in consultation with all of the interested parties and to publish a report and recommendation on this vital matter; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I have not made any such request of the Minister of State for Science and Technology.

In so far as post-primary schools are concerned, I am at present examining the scope that exists for giving more attention to science subjects. In this context, as I indicated in a reply to a recent question, I am reviewing recent initiatives in this area. These include a pilot project to encourage the study of physics and chemistry in girls' schools and a requirement that an adequate course of laboratory work be done as part of the Leaving Certificate course in physics or chemistry. I intend to encourage such initiatives and to strengthen them where necessary.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has satisfied herself that all major companies providing goods and services to schools and colleges which are funded through her Department are paying VAT as required by the Revenue Commissioners; and where such is not the case if she will publish a list of defaulting companies for the advice of school and college management bodies before the start of the next school/college year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: It is a matter for the Revenue Commissioners in the first instance to ensure that companies who are liable for VAT remit the appropriate amount of VAT due.
It would not be feasible or appropriate for my Department to issue a list of defaulting companies to schools and colleges.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Consultations with Parents' Organisations.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if her Department consults the relevant parents' organisations at school and/or national level, when the rationalisation of post-primary schools is under consideration by her Department; her views on whether parent organisations should be consulted on such matters; and the instruction she has given or will give her officials in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: It has not been my Department's practice to consult with parents' organisations at national level in the matter of rationalisation of post-primary facilities. However, it is open to such groups to make their views known to my Department either on the general issue or in respect of particular cases.

MainHeading.P: Where the question of rationalisation of post-primary facilities is being considered in respect of any area lengthy discussions and negotiations take place during which the views of all interested parties, including local parents, are taken into account.
I have made it clear to my officials that the fullest possible consultation must take place in all such cases.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if it is no longer the case in light of Labour Court Recommendation No. 10,395 regarding part-time teachers that the rates of payment of part-time teachers are a matter for determination through the teachers' conciliation council; her views on whether the question of the rates of pay and questions regarding incremental credit, superannuation arrangements, teachers' qualifications, teachers' hours, teachers' sick leave and other conditions of employment, should be matters for discussion between the representative bodies of teachers and managers involved in all sectors of post-primary education in the light of claims made on behalf of all post-primary teachers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The rates of payment of part-time teachers have not been a matter for the conciliation council. The teachers' conciliation and arbitration scheme covers whole-time teachers only and, accordingly, claims on behalf of part-time teachers are not appropriate for discussion at the conciliation council.

Labour Court Recommendation No. 10,395 relates to a claim lodged by the Teachers Union of Ireland on behalf of their members employed by City of Dublin VEC on a part-time basis. Discussions are continuing at the Labour Court concerning this recommendation.
In view of the ongoing discussions on the claim it would not be appropriate for me to make any statement in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the steps, if any she has taken or intends to take to fulfil her election programme commitment to the development of a multi-denominational primary school along the lines of the Bray, County Wicklow, Dalkey, County Dublin and Glasnevin, Dublin 7 schools; if it is her Department's policy to prohibit the patrons of such schools from establishing more than one such school each unlike the patrons of denominational schools who may establish several denominational schools within a given area; and, if so, the basis for this policy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Applications for the recognition of multi-denominational schools are considered on their merits in accordance with the prescribed criteria. There is no difference in the treatment of denominational and multi-denominational schools by my Department in regard to patronship or in any other respect.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Labour relations in Cork Regional Technical College are the responsibility of the college management and the City of Cork Vocational Education Committee in the first instance.
